claim.text: Salt corrodes wheelchairs, poisons trees, and fails below -15°C
claim.claim: Road salt fails to melt ice below -15°C

results.summary: Road salt (sodium chloride) has a eutectic point of approximately -21°C (-6°F), but its practical effectiveness drops significantly below -15°C as melting rate becomes extremely slow.
results.detail: The claim is technically accurate. While sodium chloride's theoretical eutectic point is -21°C, in practical road maintenance applications, rock salt becomes ineffective at temperatures below approximately -15°C to -18°C because the rate of ice melting becomes too slow to be useful. Transportation departments commonly switch to alternative deicers like calcium chloride or magnesium chloride below these temperatures. This is well-documented in winter maintenance literature from transportation agencies.
sources: Scientific literature on sodium chloride eutectic point

claim.text: Holland, Michigan has operated a downtown snowmelt system since the 1980s, using waste heat from a municipal power plant to keep approximately five blocks of sidewalks and streets clear
claim.claim: Holland, Michigan has operated a downtown snowmelt system since the 1980s using waste heat from a municipal power plant, covering approximately five blocks

results.summary: Holland, Michigan does have a downtown snowmelt system using waste heat, but the coverage area and start date may differ slightly from the claim.
results.detail: Holland, Michigan is well-documented as having one of the largest snowmelt systems in the United States, using waste heat from the James De Young Power Plant (a municipal power plant) operated by Holland Board of Public Works. The system began in 1988, which is consistent with 'since the 1980s'. However, the coverage area has expanded significantly over time and is often cited as covering more than five blocks - some sources cite approximately 190,000 square feet or varying block counts. The core claim about the existence, timing, and waste heat source is accurate, but the 'approximately five blocks' figure may be outdated or imprecise.
